entry.title: Re: SAC subtotal challenges
entry.content: Yes, this behavior is expected in SAP Analytics Cloud.The SUBTOTAL function has a hard limit of 10 dimensions, and there is no alternative function that removes this limit. SUBTOTAL also works only on base measures, not on aggregated or calculated measures created in the model. When used on aggregated measures, it fails by design due to calculation order restrictions. The recommended workaround is to reduce dimensions, or calculate percent of total in the source query or model instead of using SUBTOTAL.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Mass Maintenance of Tax class...
entry.content:
Dear @LukasKuhn,

In Public Cloud you basically have two hard constraints in your scenario:

  1. You can‚Äôt fix this by direct table work KNVI is just the persistence there‚Äôs no supported way to mass-update it directly in Public Cloud
  2. Migration Cockpit is not the right tool to correct existing production master data. SAP explicitly positions migration objects as initial load only

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/doc/7c9e0bbbd1664c2581b2038a1c7ae4b3/2508.500/en-US/FSD_CE2508.pdf

So re-running the same Migration Cockpit object won‚Äôt mass-correct those wrong Departure Country entries.

For a true mass correction of the country code you need an interface that can remove the wrong key-records and create the correct ones.

The released way is the Business Partner (A2X) OData API, API_BUSINESS_PARTNER specifically the entity for Sales Area Tax:

Expose the API

Set up Communication Arrangement for scenario SAP_COM_0008 (scope item 1RO) to use API_BUSINESS_PARTNER. If you don‚Äôt see SAP_COM_0008, it‚Äôs typically because scope item 1RO isn‚Äôt activated

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3357532

Identify the wrong records

Use GET on entity set A_CustomerSalesAreaTax with filters like:

  • CustomerTaxCategory: TTX1
  • DepartureCountry

More details below:

https://api.sap.com/api/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/resource/Sales_Area_Tax

https://api.sap.com/api/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/overview

Delete the wrong-key entries (mass-safe cleanup)

Create the correct entry or update if it already exists:

  • If the correct-key entry does not exist POST the correct combination
  • If it does exist and only the classification value is wrong use PATCH

SAP even has a Note showing the correct PATCH pattern and the key structure for A_CustomerSalesAreaTax and warns not to use POST for updates

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3293109

This approach is the closest equivalent to what you‚Äôre doing manually in the UI but automated and supported.

If you can‚Äôt use APIs, open an SAP Incident if you suspect the data state is blocking standard maintenance tools and you need SAP guidance for a supported correction path in your tenant.

My recommendation (cloud-friendly):

  1. Do a small pilot (5 or 10 BPs) in using API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_CustomerSalesAreaTax:
    • GET->DELETE wrong DepartureCountry rows->POST correct row or PATCH if already there
  2. Run it in mass for all affected BPs

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Incorrect Quantity / Weight Conversion during Outboun...
entry.content:
This is not a bug but a master data/customizing issue. SAP standard logic uses:

  • Material master UoM conversion factors

  • Gross/net weight maintained in material master

  • Copy control settings between SO and delivery

If any of these are inconsistent, delivery weight will be wrong even though the delivery posts successfully.

entry.title: Re: SAC - Heatmap CSS
entry.content:
No, it is not possible to apply custom colors to Heatmap rows using CSS or any other styling method in SAP Analytics Cloud.SAC does not support CSS access or custom styling at the widget or row level. The Totals row color in a Heatmap cannot be changed independently from the default theme. Conditional formatting also does not apply to Totals rows in Heatmaps.
A practical workaround is to place totals in a separate table or numeric point and style that widget instead.

entry.title: Re: Fiori Elements ValueList ComboBox
entry.content:
Hi,

Were you able to achieve this. And also what is connected_entity in this above code. I am also trying to achieve the same.

We are from the Extensibility team, working on implementing a ValueList field using the CDS extensibility feature.
Currently, the field is displayed as a single-selection dropdown in the application, but we want to make it multi-select with checkboxes.

Current Implementation

1. Create field pickListMulti under table Students

CSN used:

"extensions": [
  {
    "extend": "Students",
    "elements": {
      "pickListMulti": {
        "default": { "val": "Multi" },
        "enum": {
          "Multi": { "val": "Multi" },
          "Multi1": { "val": "Multi1" },
          "Multi2": { "val": "Multi2" }
        },
        "length": 50,
        "@Extensibility.isEditable": true,
        "type": "cds.String"
      }
    }
  }
]

2. Create table Students.pickListMulti to store the ValueList data

CSN used:

"definitions": {
  "Students.pickListMulti": {
    "kind": "entity",
    "elements": {
      "name": {
        "type": "cds.String",
        "key": true
      }
    }
  }
}

3. Create a projection/view for collection path

CSN used:

"definitions": {
  "StudentService.Students.pickListMulti": {
    "kind": "entity",
    "projection": {
      "from": { "ref": ["Students.pickListMulti"] }
    }
  }
}

4. Populate data into Students.pickListMulti entity

Data inserted using SQL INSERT commands.

5. Add ValueList annotation to expose the field

CSN used:

"extensions": [
  {
    "annotate": "StudentService.Students",
    "elements": {
      "pickListMulti": {
        "@Common.ValueList.CollectionPath": "StudentService.Students.pickListMulti",
        "@Common.ValueList.Parameters": [
          {
            "$Type": "Common.ValueListParameterInOut",
            "LocalDataProperty": "pickListMulti",
            "ValueListProperty": "name"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }
]

The above setup successfully renders pickListMulti as a ValueList dropdown, but it only supports single selection.

 

 

Tried Approaches

We tried adding the following annotations both individually and together on
StudentService.Students.pickListMulti and StudentService.Students ‚Äî but the behavior remains single-select.

"@Capabilities.FilterRestrictions": {
  "FilterExpressionRestrictions": [
    {
      "Property": "pickListMulti",
      "AllowedExpressions": "MultiValue"
    }
  ]
}

Question

Is there a way to enable multiple selection (checkboxes) for ValueList fields created through CDS extensibility?
Are we missing any additional annotation or configuration at the API/service level to make it multi-select?

entry.title: Re: Question on MDK Extension Project & Version Control B...
entry.content: Thank you, Bill, for the quick response. If I understand correctly, for each new feature we need to create a new Z extension project and include it in the base project‚Äôs .cim list. With this approach, the number of extension projects will continue to grow as new features are released. This also means we must ensure that: Extension project names are maintained in alphabetical order in the .cim file. The Overview.page is copied from the previous extension project into the new extension project so that it always contains the latest modified version of the code. Additionally, all SAP BAS projects and extension projects would be maintained within a single Git repository, initialized at the projects/ folder level. Could you please confirm if this is the recommended best practice, or point me to the appropriate documentation or SAP Learning course that describes the correct and supported approach?

entry.title: What's new in App Development and Coding Teaching Portfolio of SAP University Alliances
entry.content:
Why SAP BTP matters for teaching
SAP BTP remains the cornerstone of SAP‚Äôs strategy: it enables the clean‚Äëcore principle while demonstrating side‚Äëby‚Äëside extension patterns that safely extend SAP core systems. For academic programs preparing students for industry practice, BTP offers an integrated, modern platform for application extension, integration, data management, analytics and AI ‚Äî all in a cloud environment that maps directly to real‚Äëworld patterns.

What‚Äôs in the App Development and Coding portfolio 
Below are the principal curricula and academic experiences available now for classrooms teaching and labs. Each entry includes a placeholder for the curriculum one‚Äëpager so you can link to full instructor materials and logistics when ready.

  • SAP Build Process Automation ‚Äî Teaches how to identify, design and implement workflow automation using Build Process Automation to reduce repetitive tasks and streamline processes.
    (One‚Äëpager: link)

  • Low/No‚ÄëCode Development with SAP Build Apps ‚Äî Teaches the concepts and practice of low/no‚Äëcode app composition, connecting apps to SAP S/4HANA, and designing user experiences.
    (One‚Äëpager: link)

  • Pro‚ÄëCode Development with SAP Build Code ‚Äî Equips learners with modern pro‚Äëcode practices, including SAP Joule‚Äëassisted code generation and development workflows for scalable applications.
    (One‚Äëpager: link)

  • Pro‚ÄëCode Application Development with SAP BTP (ABAP Environment & BAS) ‚Äî Covers RAP and CAP models, RESTful application programming, and Cloud Foundry deployment to support clean‚Äëcore and side‚Äëby‚Äëside extension patterns.
    (One‚Äëpager: link)

  • SAP Integration Suite  ‚Äî Hands‚Äëon curriculum for application and data integration across cloud and on‚Äëpremise systems, using standard integration patterns and monitoring practices.
    (One‚Äëpager: link)

  • Document AI Tutorials & Global Bike extension (coming soon) ‚Äî Practical tutorials on Document AI, including an extension scenario for the Global Bike sample system to demonstrate document processing in real use cases.
    (Tutorials: link)

 

No-barrier assets for faculty: Academic Lessons
A central asset across the portfolio is the set of Academic Lessons designed to be well aligned with a typical course syllabus structure. We encourage faculty to build course syllabus around Learning Journeys and to leverage SAP cloud practice system access available through SAP Learning Hub, student edition (LHSE)  This approach gives students step‚Äëby‚Äëstep learning alongside hands‚Äëon practice in real SAP cloud systems.

 

Relevant Academic Lessons already prepared to include in a teaching pathway:

  • AI and GenAI Fundamentals (Academic Lesson)
  • Introduction to AI and SAP Business AI (Academic Lesson)
  • Low/No‚ÄëCode Composition and Automation with SAP Build Apps (Academic Lesson)

These lessons map naturally into a Learning Journey that progresses from foundational concepts (AI fundamentals, low‚Äëcode design) to applied practice (Build Apps, Integration Suite, Document AI), with optional pro‚Äëcode extensions (Build Code, ABAP/BAS). Using LHSE cloud practice access, students can complete Discovery Center missions, follow guided tutorials, and earn records of achievement and have 2 attempts of professional certifications per year.

Hands‚Äëon, flexible academic editions and support
The portfolio supports a range of academic needs: free sandboxes and trials for many BTP services, low‚Äëcost exclusive teaching environments (typical UCC offers such as 600‚Ç¨ / 1.100‚Ç¨ per half/full year), Discovery Center missions, and Train‚Äëthe‚ÄëTrainer sessions upon request. University Competence Centers (UCCs) and Academic Competence Centers (ACCs) deliver regional classroom packages and guided exercises. Faculty at SAP University Alliances member institutions can contact their local UCC/ACC or universityalliances@sap.com to get started.

Looking ahead and community engagement
In this series we will report updates, announce new Discovery Center missions available for academic use, sandboxes and pilots (including further content developments in GenAI, Agentic and Business AI), and showcase classroom case studies. We welcome your feedback and classroom experiences to help refine these materials, broaden and scale our academic portfolio.

entry.title: Story Report in Onobarding Query Design
entry.content:
Hi All,

I am facing the issue with the story report which I am building for my client.

They want to include a lot of data, i.e. personal information, biographical information, job information and data gathered during the additional data collection.

I managed to build the query which includes all of the data tables which are needed to meet the business requirement. But I am facing the following issue: not all data which is there in the onboarding dashboard, is in the report. I was modyfying the query multiple times but there is always something missing. I managed to determine that there are following issues:

- the query which contains the biographical information and linked tables (country-specific Information, dependents, email information, phone information).

- the report has the filter for legal entity used for the country which data should be visible in the report.

Removing the above from makes all the data which is missing appeared in the report. However it appears with empty rows, only the process ID is visivble, but all the rest (i.e. user ID) is empty. User ID should be there as the data collection steps are in most of the cases completed. Moreover, keeping them is needed to meet the business requirement.

I raised the support ticket with SAP, but they replied that this is due to the query design and does not fall under the scope of the product support team. There seems to be no clear documentation on how to design the query to make it working correctly.

Any feedback will be much appreciated.

I attached the screen shot of the query for your reference.

Thank you in advance.

Piotr Retecki

entry.title: Exchange Rate Difference Postings at Payment Time ‚Äì Additional 6680 / 7680 Entry in Public Cloud
entry.content:
Dear community,
 
I am working in an SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud environment and analyzing the exchange rate difference postings generated during the procurement and payment process. I have encountered a posting logic that I do not fully understand from a functional and accounting perspective.
 
I will describe the scenario in a simplified way:
‚Ä¢ Purchase order for 1,000,000 in foreign currency.
‚Ä¢ Goods Receipt posted with an exchange rate of 1.1566.
‚Ä¢ Subsequently, the Supplier Invoice is posted for the same amount (1,000,000), but with an exchange rate of 1.1727.
 
Due to the exchange rate difference between the Goods Receipt and the Invoice, the system posts an adjustment to price/variance accounts, impacting purchase or consumption accounts (for example 6011 / 6111). This behavior is clear to me.
 
Later on, the payment to the vendor is executed using an exchange rate of 1.1634.
At payment time, the accounting document contains the following postings:
‚Ä¢ Bank posting (as expected).
‚Ä¢ Clearing of the vendor account 4000 (as expected).
‚Ä¢ A negative exchange rate difference, posted to account 668 (exchange rate losses).
 
üëâ My question arises here:
 
In addition to the above, the system generates an additional accounting entry with the same amount, where:
‚Ä¢ A debit is posted to account 6680 (negative exchange rate difference), and
‚Ä¢ A corresponding credit is posted to account 7680 (positive exchange rate difference).
 
In other words, an additional posting between 6680 and 7680 is created with no net impact on P&L. While the balances offset each other, I do not fully understand the functional purpose of this posting in the context of standard exchange rate difference handling.
 
Could someone please explain why SAP generates this additional ‚Äúmirror‚Äù entry between negative and positive exchange rate difference accounts at payment time?
Is this related to the clearing or reversal of previously posted exchange rate differences, or is it part of the standard exchange rate difference logic in S/4HANA Public Cloud?
 
Many thanks in advance for your support

entry.title: SAP Central Business Configuration Best Practices During SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Upgrades
entry.content:
With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, customers benefit from regular upgrades and updates that bring the latest innovations, enhanced security, and improved performance. With SAP Central Business Configuration serving as the single entry point for scoping, organizational structures, and configuration activities, it is natural that upgrade cycles involve certain considerations within SAP Central Business Configuration.

Why Protective Measures Matter During Upgrades

Think of these measures as the safety rails on your system. By locking down critical operations (transports, data migrations, extensibility) during upgrade windows, SAP ensures the upgrade process can run smoothly without unintended side effects ‚àí protecting the system from half-done changes or version mismatches.

With SAP rolling out major upgrades twice a year (typically in February and August) and regular updates (hotfix collections) every two weeks between major upgrades, having a clear restriction schedule allows customers to adopt innovations in a controlled, manageable way. For more information on the schedule, please refer to:

  • Upgrade & Maintenance Schedule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-System Landscape
  • Upgrade & Maintenance Schedule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 2-System Landscape

Protective Measures and Best Practices

  • Keep your team well informed about upcoming upgrade cycles.
  • Avoid initial activation around upgrade time, as it‚Äôs typically time consuming.
  • Avoid large deploymentsto prevent stuck deployments or partial content activation.
  • Perform business configuration activities until 8 hours before system downtime.
  • Make changes to your scope or organizational structure up until the content upgrade begins.
  • For the parallel line, avoid initiating rebase and merge before the upgrade starts, as these actions lock the workspace.
  • Avoid scheduling critical go-lives and User Acceptance Testing (UAT) around upgrades.
  • For the 2-system landscape, in addition to the above, avoid releasing transport requests from the quality system to the production system.

SAP Central Business Configuration Impacts

Let‚Äôs look at how the SAP Central Business Configuration system behaves during these system upgrades.

1. During Update: Here‚Äôs the update maintenance schedule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-system landscape:

Update windows and time of workspace locking per region

  • Please note that deployments are automatically locked 12 hours before the software update starts, aligning with the timing of the Major Upgrade Window (MUW).
  • Business configuration activities can be performed until the system enters downtime.
  • Organizational structure updates, scope extensions, and new country activations are allowed until the content update begins and the SAP Central Business Configuration workspace becomes locked. 

2. During Upgrade: Here‚Äôs the upgrade maintenance schedule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-system landscape:

Upgrade windows and time of workspace locking per region

  • Please note that deployments are automatically locked 30 hours before the software upgrade starts, aligning with the timing of the Major Upgrade Window (MUW).
  • Business configuration activities can be performed until 12 hours before the system enters downtime.

Organizational structure updates, scope extensions, and new country activations are allowed until the content update begins and the SAP Central Business Configuration workspace becomes locked.

References
To learn more, check out the following resources:

  • SAP Note 3215993 (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-System Landscape)
  • SAP Note 3464889 (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 2-System Landscape)

That wraps up the new features this time. Did you like this blog? If so, please leave us a thumbs up at the top. Also, make sure to follow the SAP Central Business Configuration tag or follow this dedicated blog collection to stay up to date with the latest blog posts.

entry.title: Enhancing Business Processes with SAP BTP AI in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Preface

Modern enterprises increasingly expect their integration platforms to do more than reliably move data between systems. SAP Integration Suite, combined with SAP BTP AI services, provides a foundation to embed intelligence directly into integration flows. This post highlights how combining integration with AI can unlock new capabilities and drive smarter, more adaptive processes across the enterprise.

Introduction

Enterprise integrations traditionally rely on deterministic, structured data‚Äîa design paradigm that has supported SAP business processes for decades. This determinism is what allows ERP systems to automatically and reliably create documents, update statuses, or trigger follow-on actions.

When a payload arrives in a predefined, standard format‚Äîvia interfaces such as APIs, IDocs, or RFCs‚Äîthe ERP system can create a business document and drive it forward to the furthest possible system-determined state, guided entirely by the incoming structured fields and the process logic configured within SAP ERP.

For example, an incoming ORDERS05 IDoc carries fields such as BSART (document type), VKORG (sales organization), KUNNR (sold-to), MATNR, MENGE, and PSTYV (item category). Each of these fields is restricted to predefined, allowed values and mapped to controlled domains in SAP‚Äîdocument types, organizational structures, master data, and item categories. Because of this, the system can deterministically derive pricing, partner functions, credit checks, availability checks, and subsequent status movements without any human involvement.

However, many real-world processes reach a designed stopping point‚Äînot due to technical limitations, but because a critical decision input exists only as free-text narrative that requires interpretation. At this point, the system can no longer progress deterministically.

One scenario where this consistently occurs is when free-text inputs determine the next business action. High-value examples include:

  1. customer return comments in RMAs (Return Merchandise Authorization), capturing defect descriptions, expectations, or reason narratives;
  2. exception remarks on delivery notes, such as damage details, refusal reasons, or access issues; and
  3. justification text in travel expense claims, explaining non-compliant or unusual charges.

These narrative fields often dictate the downstream outcome‚Äîwhether a return is approved, a delivery is blocked, or an expense is reimbursed‚Äîbut only after a human reads and interprets them.

GenAI as the Semantic Bridge

Recent advances in Generative AI ‚Äî powered by large language models (LLMs) ‚Äî make it possible to automate this traditionally human-only interpretation step. These models can read the free-form comments contained in incoming messages, infer intent and context, and return structured, process-ready attributes in a fast and consistent manner, which the integration layer can pass directly into ERP.

To realize this, the integration flow could simply call the LLM and instruct it to convert narrative comments into ERP-compatible attributes, codes, or flags. The model applies reasoning to questions such as:

  • Is the customer asking for a refund or a replacement?
  • Is the delivery refusal due to damage or customer unavailability?
  • Is the expense violation justified or not justified?

Based on this, the model produces clean ERP-friendly outputs, for example:

  • ReturnActionCode = "REFUND" or "REPLACEMENT"
  • DeliveryBlockReason = "DAMAGED_GOODS" or "CUSTOMER_NOT_AVAILABLE"
  • ExpenseExceptionStatus = "APPROVED_JUSTIFIED" or "REJECTED_UNJUSTIFIED"

Instead of receiving verbose, unstructured text that a human must interpret, the backend now receives clear, deterministic signals it can immediately act on ‚Äî allowing the business process to progress further downstream rather than stopping at the point where human intervention was previously required.

Deep Dive Example: Customer Returns (As-Is vs. AI-Enhanced Flow)

Let us consider a model company named Smart Sense Technologies (SST), a global manufacturer of smart security devices. Like many enterprises today, SST‚Äôs IT organization faces both challenges and opportunities driven by internal and external factors such as a rapidly evolving technology landscape, shifting customer expectations, and increasing business demand for speed and agility. To respond effectively and deliver optimal outcomes for its stakeholders, SST embarked on a digital transformation journey supported by SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). The organization leverages BTP to innovate and extend business capabilities, enabling greater process efficiency, faster time-to-market, and increased operational agility. To stay ahead of the competition, SST continuously evaluates and optimizes its end-to-end business processes.

In the As-Is process, SST‚Äôs customer returns initiated in SAP Commerce Cloud are integrated with SAP S/4HANA using the standard SAP Commerce Cloud Integration with SAP S/4HANA. This package provides a ready-made integration flow that transmits return requests from Commerce Cloud to S/4HANA as ORDERS05 IDocs, establishing a reliable and widely adopted baseline for returns processing.

This iflow sends the transactional data required to create the returns order in S/4HANA. Along with structured order attributes, it also forwards free-text return comments entered by the customer. These narrative descriptions are embedded in the IDoc and successfully persisted in the returns document, but they are not interpreted or acted upon automatically by the system.

Read: For more background on the Sales & Return process integration using IDOC.

At the IDoc level, two fields are particularly relevant in this context. E1EDP01-ABGRT carries the free-text return or cancellation description provided upstream, while E1EDP01-ABGRU represents the structured rejection or decision reason that drives subsequent processing in Sales and Returns Management. In real-world configurations, ABGRT is commonly populated by the inbound integration, whereas ABGRU is often left empty until a human has reviewed the return and made a decision.

It is also important to note that approval responsibilities may vary by landscape. In some scenarios, return approval may already occur in an upstream portal such as SAP Commerce Cloud in our example, while in others it is intentionally deferred to SAP S/4HANA. For the purpose of this example, we assume that the approval step is handled in S/4HANA. As a result, when the ORDERS05 IDoc arrives from Commerce Cloud, the return order is created with descriptive context (ABGRT) but without a decision code (ABGRU), causing the process to pause for human review.

As part of SST‚Äôs continuous improvement efforts, the IT organization is tasked with the responsibility to help the business improve its processes ‚Äì with specific metrics such as cutting sales / return processing lead-time, improving accuracy, offering consistent customer experience. Considering this, SST‚Äôs integration architecture team proposes a solution leveraging BTP AI within Integration Suite iflow.

In this scenario, SST extends the standard integration flow with a focused AI-based classification step executed in a post-exit iflow in SAP Integration Suite. The free-text return description (ABGRT) received from SAP Commerce Cloud is passed to an LLM using a tightly constrained prompt that maps narrative customer input to a single, predefined SAP rejection reason code.

The following figure shows the Post-exit iflow that is called from the main flow. This iflow uses AI adapter to call an LLM to convert the free-text customer rejection comments into a deterministic return code.

Here, we pass the prompt directly from the processing tab of the AI Adapter, with the rejection text as parameter, that is fetched from the incoming message from Commerce cloud.

After deploying the post-exit iflow, next we proceed to test using a HTTP client (to mimic a message from SAP Commerce cloud). Here, rejection text is parameterized and fed from a variable.

The rejection text is passed as ‚ÄúItem arrived much later than agreed‚Äù.

This is the actual prompt that is sent to the LLM ‚Äì after substitution of the rejection text, passed from the HTTP call.

The following is the LLM response, with S4_RejectionReasonCode being populated, strictly adhering to the prompting made to the LLM.

Next, we use this LLM derived RejectionReasonCode to enrich the IDOC mapping, to populate E1EDP01-ABGRU.

As demonstrated in the preceding steps, the extended integration flow now enriches the inbound ORDERS05 IDoc with a populated rejection reason code (ABGRU), derived from the customer‚Äôs free-text input (ABGRT) using AI-based reasoning and interpretation. With the decision code present at creation time, the returns document no longer stalls in an indeterminate state and can proceed through the standard S/4HANA returns process without waiting for manual interpretation.

Depending on landscape design and process ownership, this semantic enrichment can also be taken a step further. Instead of‚Äîor in addition to‚Äîpopulating the IDoc, the same inferred outcome can be used to directly invoke standard SAP S/4HANA APIs such as the Advanced Returns Management approval service (API_CUSTOMER_RETURN_SRV) to explicitly release or reject the return order. This represents the post‚Äìhuman-action document state that would traditionally be reached only after a manual approval step.

Together, these patterns illustrate how introducing AI-driven interpretation at the integration layer allows unstructured customer intent to be converted into structured, actionable business signals at the point of entry.

AI in Integration: Why It Fits and How to Govern It

1) Reasserted: The Integration platform‚Äôs timeless role as the enabler of Process Integration

In many enterprises, the integration layer, such as Integration Suite, serves as the natural ingestion point and middleware platform that facilitates transactions and orchestrates message flows between applications across the ERP landscape. Embedding GenAI-driven interpretation here fits naturally into CPI‚Äôs existing responsibilities: it allows the business meaning hidden inside narrative text to be converted into actionable signals before the request reaches the core ERP process. For integration architects and developers, this aligns perfectly with the integration layer‚Äôs role as the control point for routing, orchestration, and decisioning.

When free-text descriptions are converted into deterministic attributes‚Äîsuch as return_reason_code, refund_flag, inspection_required, or damage_classification‚ÄîCPI can now call the exact API operation that corresponds to the post-review document state. In other words, CPI can directly invoke the relevant API to post the document in the status it would have reached only after a human had read, approved, or actioned the text. This removes the need to always invoke a ‚Äúpre-review‚Äù API and wait for downstream human review.

This shift eliminates traditional bottlenecks: manual interpretation steps, workflow inbox approvals, delays from human availability, and intermediate document states that halt progression. Because decisioning happens at the moment the request enters the landscape, CPI sends a clean, enriched, decision-ready payload to S/4HANA (or any backend), enabling the system to execute the correct business logic immediately.

Rather than replacing human judgment, this pattern formalizes and codifies human insight into a governed, automated, and fully auditable integration layer. This is why, in this scenario, AI belongs in the integration layer: This architectural capability empowers CPI to transform narrative inputs into deterministic, actionable signals, enabling downstream process automation while keeping the ERP core clean.

2) Clean Core by Design

Placing the intelligence in SAP BTP ensures that ERP systems remain standard, maintainable, and free from any text-interpretation logic. This approach avoids enhancing S/4HANA to parse unstructured text or extending it to process AI-derived attributes‚Äîboth of which introduce long-term complexity and technical debt.

Instead, ERP systems receive clean, structured, enriched payloads through the REST/OData APIs designed for standard CRUD operations. This keeps backend applications stable and upgrade-friendly, while positioning the intelligence in a layer that is flexible, governed, and purpose-built to support innovation. By keeping the semantics outside the ERP and feeding it deterministic attributes through established integration patterns, the core remains clean by design.

3) A Perfect Problem‚ÄìSolution Fit for AI

Interpretation of natural-language free text is inherently a language-understanding problem ‚Äî a task that humans have traditionally handled because it requires context, nuance, and inference. GenAI models excel exactly in this domain: extracting meaning, identifying intent, and classifying the actions implied by narrative input.
Once the integration layer converts this text into deterministic attributes, every subsequent step becomes standard ERP automation ‚Äî pricing behaviour, blocking, approvals, follow-on documents, status progression, and more.

4) High Business Value When Applied to High-Impact Scenarios

A clear business value emerges when Generative AI is applied to the right type of problem‚Äîspecifically, scenarios where narrative text shapes important decisions. While many processes contain free-text fields, the highest value appears when unstructured descriptions create friction, ambiguity, or costly delays that materially affect customer satisfaction, compliance, or financial outcomes. The architectural decision to integrate an LLM must be strictly justified by a measurable Return on Investment (ROI), as these models operate on a metered consumption model. Consequently, the value delivered must always outweigh the cost of the service call, meaning GenAI should be applied only to high-impact, high-volume scenarios where the operational expense of manual intervention significantly exceeds the cost of an LLM call.

Typical examples of processes (as previously mentioned) that run at scale, carry high consequence, and often suffer from a high cost of delay include: Customer Returns (RMAs), delivery exceptions, and expense justifications. In these situations, shifting the interpretation logic to the point of ingestion (within the Integration Suite) fundamentally reshapes the flow. Processing accelerates because items no longer wait for manual review; accuracy and consistency improve through uniform, model-driven interpretation; and downstream data quality is strengthened. This leads to tangible improvements in efficiency and decision reliability, with human attention reserved for genuine edge cases. Scenarios that combine high repetition, high consequence, and high ambiguity are the strongest candidates for this GenAI-driven interpretation, whereas traditional deterministic approaches remain the appropriate and cost-effective choice when these characteristics are absent.

5) Auditability and Control Built In

While in our deep-dive example, we directly applied the prompt at the AI Adapter, it is also possible to build the request body, incorporating orchestration configurations provided out of the box with BTP AI Core (GenAI Hub), in the form of LLM guard-railing steps such as prompt templating, data masking, model configuration, and so on. Also, it is a best practice to make use of prompt templates, to make use of reusability. With such controls in place, the LLM response can stay relevant, reliable, and responsible (3 ‚ÄúR‚Äùs that constitute the key pillars of SAP's AI strategy) ensuring that business process outcomes are explainable and auditable.

These details about Orchestration workflow can be found in this SAP help portal page.

I‚Äôd also recommend that you read this blog by my colleague Daniil, where Orchestration workflow in Generative AI Hub is used to invoke an LLM in a secure, GDPR-compliant way, from within an integration flow.

Conclusion

By leveraging SAP BTP AI services within SAP Integration Suite, organizations can elevate integration from a transport layer to a semantic processing layer‚Äîconverting human intent into deterministic business signals at the point of entry. This approach enables Straight-Through Processing, automating decision-making while preserving governance, auditability, and maintainability.

Combining Integration and AI opens up new possibilities for business process efficiency. Are you examining how this could apply within your own landscape?

Read our earlier article on how BTP‚Äôs AI Services can help in your Integration flow‚Äôs routing, decision-making steps.

entry.title: What Rising Beef Prices Reveal in SAP Business Network Spend Trends
entry.content:
The New York Times reported the average price of a pound of ground beef was around $6.32 in September. This is an increase of about 11‚àí14% from the previous year, driven primarily by a smaller U.S. cattle herd.  As global temperatures rise, shrinking cattle herds are straining the nation's beef supply even as demand remains strong.  As of July, USDA data shows there were 28.7 million beef cows across the US, the lowest number in decades.  Other factors lifting beef prices include higher grain costs and labor supply shortages at slaughterhouses.  Furthermore, tariffs on beef from Brazil, America's largest import source, may be curbing supplies.  The total tariff on Brazilian beef imports sat at 76.4% in September, according to the American Farm Bureau Federation.

You may be asking if spending on SAP Business Network reflects these economic factors. Here is what network data shows.  Two meat classes are traded on SBN:

  • Processed Meat & Poultry Processed meat has undergone additional treatment beyond basic cutting or packaging. Examples include deli meats (ham, turkey breast slices, roast beef), sausages, hot dogs, bratwurst, bacon, chicken nuggets or patties.
  • Minimally Processed Meat & Poultry These products undergo only basic processing needed to make them safe or convenient.  Examples include raw chicken breasts, thighs, or wings, raw turkey or whole chickens, and ground beef or ground turkey.

Beef cannot be analyzed in isolation until we extend demand trends to level 4 of UNSPSC.

 

There‚Äôs $364M in spend of processed meat on the network.  There was a large spike spread over Q3 with spend increase 76.4% compared to the prior quarter.

 

The plot thickens however when viewing minimally processed meats.  Minimally processed meat spend was $578M and relatively flat with an extreme spike in September.  Q3 spend increased 43% compared to Q2.

 

Analysts have observed differences in behavior of both classes.  Analysts say:

  • minimally processed meat has steadier baseline demand but more volatility due to supply constraints, inflation, and contract timing.
  • processed meat shows steady, healthy growth driven by convenience and value-added products.

SBN data appears to support both of these observations as exhibited by the following:

  • Steady growth of processed meat from February ‚Äì September with few dips
  • Processed meat less volatile. No extreme spikes or crashes.
  • Minimally processed meat is more volatile. Large swings early year from December ‚Äì February.
  • Minimally processed meat shows occasional extreme spikes. The 147M spike in September.
  • Minimally processed demand tied more to supply chain fluctuations.  Jumps and reversals in monthly data.

entry.title: Integration Advisor ‚Äì Use Custom XSLT as MAG
entry.content:
I am excited to announce our latest feature: Within the Integration Advisor capability of SAP Integration Suite, you can now define a Mapping Guideline (MAG) using a custom XSLT file. In this blog post, I will provide a brief overview of this new feature and explain how to use it.  

Motivation

Integration Advisor, through its MAG Editor, provides a tool that enables Business Experts or Integration Developers to implement mappings between different message structures. The MAG Editor is specifically designed for B2B interactions and includes numerous value-added features, particularly useful for handling EDI messages (such as qualification concept, code value mapping, date-time conversion, and proposal service). One of the key advantages of the MAG Editor is its graphical mapping approach, which empowers Business Experts without developer skills to define mappings with minimal assistance from Integration Developers (following a no-code/low-code approach).

But there are scenarios where customers prefer to use a custom XSLT file instead of a graphical mapping. Such use cases include: 

  • Significant structural differences between the source and target message that cannot be easily resolved by a graphical mapping editor like the MAG Editor.
  • The need for additional pre- or post-processing steps (in addition to a graphical mapping) that can be handled more efficiently using XSLT.
  • A desire to reuse an existing XSLT mapping file, for instance, from another mapping platform such as SAP Process Integration.  

In the past, this functionality could already be achieved through a separate mapping step (of type XSLT) in Cloud Integration or via a Process Direct configuration in Trading Partner Management (TPM). 

Through the SAP Customer Influence program, we received the requirement to enable custom XSLT mappings directly within Integration Advisor (see Link). The advantage of this approach is the ability to maintain all graphical and XSLT mapping artifacts in one place, leverage Integration Advisor's versioning capabilities, and reach a unified configuration in Trading Partner Management.   

Feature Description 

When creating a new Mapping Guideline (MAG), you now have the option to choose between a Graphical MAG (either Standard or Overlay) and an XSLT MAG. When selecting the XSLT option, the MAG is defined in the traditional way by selecting Source and Target Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs). 

After the MAG is created, you can upload your custom XSLT file. (Please note that the MAG must be saved before the XSLT file is applied.) The screenshot below illustrates the appearance of an XSLT MAG.

 You can view the content of the uploaded XSLT file, download it, and re-upload an updated XSLT file if needed. Additionally, you can use the Simulate MAG feature in the same way as for a Graphical MAG. We also plan to introduce an option to validate the XSLT syntax of your file soon. 

Please note that it is not possible to edit the content of the XSLT file directly within Integration Advisor. If updates are required, you can make the necessary changes in your preferred XSLT editor and re-upload the XSLT file. Furthermore, certain configurations available for Graphical MAGs, such as Global Parameters, Shared Code, Duplicate Target Nodes, or Pretransformation, are not applicable to XSLT MAGs and are therefore not offered in the UI.

And one final comment regarding the specific XSLT in the screenshot above: The Ship Notice message (856) from ASC X12 frequently requires a very specific structure for the HL Segment Groups in terms of order and identifiers. It is a well-known issue that graphical mapping editors, such as the MAG Editor, often face challenges in producing all the required details. In such cases, we recommend utilizing an additional XSLT as post-processing - see this blog post (Link) for a detailed explanation. The example above illustrates how this XSLT would appear as an XSLT MAG.

Two Architectural Assumptions  

The purpose of this new feature is to achieve closer integration of custom XSLT mappings within the Integration Advisor framework. In this section, I would like to highlight two key design decisions made to support this purpose. If you plan to use this feature, please keep these two aspects in mind: 

1. An XSLT MAG maps between a Source and a Target MIG

  • Explanation: Similar to current Graphical MAGs, you need to define a Source MIG and a Target MIG for your custom XSLT mapping.
  • Reasoning:
    • Aligns with the current principal design of Integration Advisor.
    • Ensures seamless integration into Trading Partner Management (if TPM is utilized).
    • Allows MAG Simulation to function similarly to Graphical MAGs.

2. An XSLT MAG works with Integration Advisor Payload Format (ICA format)

  • Explanation:
    • Background: We call the payload format after applying MIG preproc.xslt the ICA payload format. This format differs from the original XML payload format (called CPI payload format) in several aspects, most notably added qualifier suffixes but also other processing simplifications (e.g., the inclusion of an extra node CONTENT for nodes based on XSD Simple Content).
    • Similar to Graphical MAGs, the custom XSLT shall map between the ICA payload format of the Source MIG and the ICA payload format of the Target MIG.
  • Reasoning:
    • Aligns with the current principal design of Integration Advisor.
    • Ensures seamless integration into Trading Partner Management (if TPM is used).
    • Maintains consistent processing steps in Integration Flows within Cloud Integration (if TPM is not used), allowing the same Integration Flow logic as for Graphical MAGs.
  • Advantage: 
    • Leverages Integration Advisor's value-added features, such as the powerful MIG qualification concept, which could also simplify a custom XSLT mapping.
    • Enables the use of Extended Semantic Payload Validation based on your MIG.
  • (Potential) Disadvantage: If you already have an XSLT file that maps between standard XML formats (CPI format or PO format), you may need to make some adjustments to work with the ICA payload format.
  • Additional info: The Integration Advisor Payload Format is depicted by the MIG structure you see in MIG Editor or MAG Editor. By clicking on a node, you can navigate to the Technical Information section to find the exact XML Node Name and the exact Node XPath, which need to be used to address a node. See screenshot below for an example.

If these two architectural assumptions do not align with your use case, you can still utilize the XSLT mapping feature of Cloud Integration or the Process Direct option in TPM. In such cases, you have greater flexibility in your design decisions but will not benefit from the closer integration with Integration Advisor. 

Consumption in Trading Partner Management and Cloud Integration

When you export the runtime artifacts of an XSLT MAG, there is no difference compared to a Graphical MAG. The runtime artifacts include a mapping XSLT file, which is named according to your MAG Name. This exported MAG XSLT file contains the XSLT definitions you uploaded in your XSLT MAG.

Using this approach, you can consume an XSLT MAG in Trading Partner Management as well as in Cloud Integration in the same way as you would consume a Graphical MAG.  

Conclusion

With this new feature, you can create a Mapping Guideline in Integration Advisor based on your own custom XSLT file. This provides greater flexibility where needed while still leveraging Integration Advisor features such as versioning and integration with TPM.

Looking ahead, we plan to introduce an additional standard feature in TPM/IA that will allow you to combine multiple MAGs in a mapping sequence. This would enable scenarios where you can combine a Graphical MAG with additional XSLT pre- and/or post-processing.  

Further reading

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blogs-by-sap/integration-advisor-overview-of-components-for-... 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blogs-by-sap/integration-content-advisor-create-a-customized... 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/integration-content-advisor-create-a-mapping-using-mag-editor/ba-p/13424264 

https://community.sap.com/t5/integration-blog-posts/taming-the-x12-856-message-in-sap-integration-advisor-a-step-by-step-guide/ba-p/14115410

entry.title: Designing an Effective Grievance Process in SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals Management
entry.content:
Employee trust in the performance management process depends heavily on transparency, fairness, and the ability to raise concerns. A well-designed Grievance Process in SAP SuccessFactors Performance and Goals Management (PMGM) ensures that employees can formally challenge or seek clarification on performance outcomes, while HR and management can handle these cases in a structured, auditable way.

This blog explains how to design and configure a grievance process in SuccessFactors PMGM using:

  • Performance Management (PM) Templates
  • Route Maps
  • Business Rules
  • Add Review Steps upon form routing
  • Dynamically control field visibility, editability, and required status

Why Build a Grievance Process in PMGM?
A grievance process in PMGM enables organizations to:

  • Provide a formal appeal mechanism for performance ratings
  • Ensure consistency and compliance across regions
  • Improve employee confidence in performance outcomes
  • Maintain auditability of all actions and comments
  • Reduce off-system emails and manual escalations

Instead of managing grievances outside SuccessFactors, organizations can embed the process directly into the performance form lifecycle.

High-Level Grievance Process Flow
A typical grievance flow in PMGM looks like this:

  • Employee Submits Grievance Request
  • Additional Review Steps Triggered
  • HR / Grievance Committee Review
  • Final Decision Communicated
  • Form Completed & Locked

This flow is achieved using a combination of PM template fields, route maps, and intelligent business rules.

Step 1: Configuring the PM Template for Grievance Handling

Key Fields to Add in the PM Template

Add custom fields in the relevant sections (Summary / Overall Rating / Custom Section)

üí° Best Practice: Place employee-facing grievance fields in a separate custom section for clarity.

 

Step 2: Designing the Route Map with Conditional Grievance Steps

Route Maps control who sees the form and when.

Enable ‚ÄúHidden Until Rule Execution‚Äù option in all the route steps which you want to use in the business rule.

Step 3: Add Review Steps Upon Form Routing (Business Rule)

One of the most powerful capabilities in PMGM is dynamically adding route map steps when specific conditions are met.

Step 4: Controlling Field Visibility, Editability, and Mandatory Status Using Business Rules

A grievance process requires different users to see different fields at different times.

This is achieved using Business Rules for Field Properties.

Step 5: In the Assign Rules in Talent admin tool, you've assigned the rule to the Field Change trigger.

Once the business rule is assigned to a template, Admin can launch a form and meet the conditions to trigger the additional steps.

 

Reporting & Audit Considerations
To strengthen governance:

  • Use Story or Table Reports to track:
  • Number of grievances raised
  • Approval vs rejection trends
  • Average grievance resolution time
  • Enable field audit history for grievance-related fields
  • Maintain role-based permissions strictly

Conclusion

By combining PM Templates, Route Maps, and Business Rules, SAP SuccessFactors PMGM provides a robust and flexible framework to manage employee grievances within the performance cycle.
A well-implemented grievance process not only improves compliance and transparency but also reinforces employee trust in performance management outcomes.

entry.title: Re: We are facing an issue with barcode scanning on a Hon...
entry.content:
The barcode scanner icon in the search bar and in the simple property field both will open the camera by default to try and scan a barcode and place the value into the respective field.   MDK also provides a way to override this and execute a custom rule to use a hardware scanner for example.  Integration of any other scanner is not provided out of the box from MDK.

How are you using the scanner in this case?

  1. Are using the default camera scanning as defined out of the box?
  2. Are you defining an OnScanPress rule for your SimpleProperty field?
  3. Are you using the "keyboard wedge" mode of the hardware scanner?

entry.title: How to transport variants and bookmarks in SAP Fiori Launchpad | Part 1 - Introduction
entry.content:
How variants are transported via GUI

If you have created a new variant in ERP development system and want to maintain them to the test and production system you can simply add them to a transport request using program RSTRANSP (via transaction SE38). Once the transport request is released all variants will be imported into all subsequent systems (DEV - QAS - PROD) according to your transport and system settings.

Programm RSTRANSP

SAP Fiori Launchpad and Fiori Apps

In the SAP Fiori Launchpad, you‚Äôll find different types of Fiori Apps, including:

  • GUI-to-HTML Fiori Apps,
  • UI5 Fiori Apps and
  • Web Dynpro Fiori Apps.

How to identify the type of a Fiori App: To determine which type of SAP Fiori App you‚Äôre using, follow these simple steps:

  1. Open the Fiori App.
  2. Click on the initials in the upper-right corner.
  3. Select "About" from the menu.
  4. In the dialog box that appears, check the "Framework ID" section - this will indicate the app type.

Examples:

  • The "Trial Balance" (F0996) app is a Web Dynpro Fiori App.
  • The "Audit Journal" (F0997) app is a UI5 Fiori App.
  • The "Display Asset" (AS03) app is a GUI-to-HTML Fiori App.

Fiori App "Trial Balance" (F0996) 

Fiori App "Audit Journal" (F0997)

Fiori App "Display Asset" (AS03)

Now that we‚Äôve explored how to locate different Fiori Apps, our next two blog posts will take a closer look at UI5 Apps and Web Dynpro Apps. GUI-to-HTML Apps won‚Äôt be covered in a separate post since the process remains unchanged from what was explained at the beginning.

Here‚Äôs a sneak peek at the next two blog posts in this series. For a deeper dive, stay tuned!

How to transport variants and bookmarks - Overview

Blog Series "How to transport variants and bookmarks in SAP Fiori Launchpad"

  • Part 1 - Introduction
  • Part 2 - UI5 Fiori Apps
  • Part 3 - Web Dynpro Fiori Apps

Happy learning! Read you in the next part.

entry.title: How to transport variants and bookmarks in SAP Fiori Launchpad | Part 2 - UI5 Fiori Apps
entry.content:
How to transport in UI5 Fiori Apps

Now that we‚Äôve explored the different types of Fiori Apps, let‚Äôs dive deeper into the first category. Referring to the chart from the initial blog post in this series, we‚Äôll focus on the left section of the diagram and start with UI5 Fiori Apps.

How to transport variants and bookmarks - Overview

Not all SAP Fiori Apps support the AdaptUI function, even though they are built on SAPUI5 technology. The key distinction is that while an app may be a UI5 application, AdaptUI can be explicitly disabled. Examples:

  • Fiori App "Display G/L Account Balances" (ID: F0707A) - AdaptUI not active
  • Fiori App "Manage Supplier Line Items" (ID: F0712) - AdaptUI active

Activate AdaptUI

Fiori App "Display G/L Account Balances" (ID: F0707A) ID: F0707A - AdaptUI not active

 

 Fiori App "Manage Supplier Line Items" (ID: F0712) ID: F0712 - AdaptUI active

Depending on whether AdaptUI is active or not, please follow the corresponding instructions explained in this blog post.
Before proceeding, ensure you have a workbench request created.

AdaptUI active - step-by-step instruction

Step 1: Login to Fiori Launchpad development system.

Step 2: Open Fiori App, then click on your user icon in the top-left corner and select "Adapt UI".

AdaptUI active - Step 2

Step 3: In the newly visible toolbar, navigate to the "Navigation" tab.

Step 4: Define selection criteria for each field you wish to include in the variant.

AdaptUI activ - Step 3 and 4

Step 5: Return to the "UI Adaptation" tab.

Step 6: Click the arrow next to "Standard" and select "Save View As".

Step 7: Activate the new version by clicking the wand icon.

Step 8: Add the variant to the workbench request by selecting the truck icon.

Step 9: Exit Adapt UI and release the workbench request.

AdaptUI active - Step 5 to 9

You can use the same instruction for layouts in UI5 Apps where AdaptUI is active.

AdaptUI not active - step-by-step instruction

Instruction reference : Note 3196205 - How to migrate the variants/views of UI5 apps from one system to the other system. Before you start make sure you have a workbench request created.

How to transport variants and bookmarks - Overview

Step 1: Login to the Fiori Launchpad development system.

Step 2: Create the variant and save it.

Step 3: Execute program /UIF/MIGRATE_FES_PERSO via transaction SE38. Enter the user that was used to create the variant.

AdaptUI not active - Step 3

Step 4: Deselect the "Test mode" option and assign a workbench request. Run the program (F8) and release the workbench request afterward.

AdaptUI not active - Step 4

In the next and last part we will focus on Web Dynpro Apps.

Blog Series "How to transport variants and bookmarks in SAP Fiori Launchpad"

  • Part 1 - Introduction
  • Part 2 - UI5 Fiori Apps
  • Part 3 - Web Dynpro Fiori Apps

Happy learning! Read you in the next part.

entry.title: How to transport variants and bookmarks in SAP Fiori Launchpad | Part 3 - Web Dynpro Fiori Apps
entry.content:
How to transport in Web Dynpro Fiori Apps

This is the final blog post in the series "How to transport variants and bookmarks in SAP Fiori Launchpad." In this concluding part, we'll focus on the last segment of the process - Web Dynpro Apps. Here, it is essential to distinguish between the transportation of variants and bookmarks.

This procedure for variants is based on Note 3386445 - FPM_SEARCH_UIBB and outlines the steps for transporting saved variants in WebDynpro applications.
The instruction for bookmarks is based on Note 3336542 - BICS Data Grid: Transport of Bookmarks. 

How to transport variants and bookmarks - Overview

Before proceeding, ensure that a transport request has been created.

Transport of variants - step-by-step instruction

Step 1: Login to the Fiori Launchpad development system.

Step 2: Create a variant (in this scenario "Asset History Sheet" Fiori App is used).

Transport of variants - Step 2

Step 3: Save the variant as public.

Transport of variants - Step 3

Step 4: Run program FPM_SEARCH_TRANSPORT_VIEWS in transaction SE38. Select the configuration ID of the variant and execute (F8).

Transport of variants - Step 4

Step 5: Each line represents a variant. Select the relevant entries and add them to the transport request by clicking the truck icon. Once all variants are added, release the transport.

Transport of variants - Step 5

Step 6: Login to the test system (or the target system where the variants should be imported).

Step 7: Execute program FPM_SEARCH_IMPORT_SSEARCH in SE38. Note: This import must be performed in each client.

Transport of variants - Step 7

Step 8: Execute test run to verify the number of variants to be imported. Execute in production mode to complete the import.

 

Transport of bookmarks - step-by-step instruction

Step 1: Login to the Fiori Launchpad development system (in this scenario the user is called VARIANT).

Step 2: Create bookmark and save it as public. Note: To create a bookmark, the system must contain data - at least one posting. Without data, you are not able to add or rearrange columns and rows.

Step 3: Run program FPM_BICS_TRANSPORT_BOOKMARKS in SE38.

Transport of bookmarks - Step 3

Step 4: Enter or select your query. Note: How to find the related query? Open the Fiori App Library and search for your corresponding Fiori App. Then click on tab "Implementation Information" and open the "Configuration" section.  Scroll down to the Bsa Query.

Transport of bookmarks - Step 4

Step 5: Execute the program (F8). Select the bookmark from the list and add it to a transport request by clicking the truck icon.

Transport of bookmarks- Step 5

Step 6: Login to the target system where the bookmark should be imported.

Step 7: Execute import report: run SE38 and execute FPM_BICS_IMPORT_BOOKMARKS. Deselect test run and execute the program.

Transport of bookmarks - Step 7

Blog Series "How to transport variants and bookmarks in SAP Fiori Launchpad"

  • Part 1 - Introduction
  • Part 2 - UI5 Fiori Apps
  • Part 3 - Web Dynpro Fiori Apps

Happy learning!

entry.title: ABAP RAP - Download any kind of file from RAP application object page
entry.content:
To the best of my knowledge, there is no built-in solution in RAP applications to add a 'Download' action on the object page without resorting to custom UI5 JavaScript coding.

This can be very useful when you need to download a file that is generated dynamically (such as an Adobe form, SmartForm, or any type of flat file). The ABAP RAP framework only provides upload/download functionality for objects stored in database tables.

In this blog post, I aim to present a simple workaround that enables adding a download button which triggers custom code to generate the file.

The concept is straightforward: create a virtual element (in fact, three virtual elements) in the consumption view and apply the appropriate file management annotations. In my example, I wanted to enable downloading a JSON file (hence the naming), but as mentioned earlier, this approach works for any type of file.

@ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_VIRTUAL_CALC'
@Semantics.largeObject: { fileName: 'jsonFileName', mimeType: 'jsonMimeType', contentDispositionPreference: #ATTACHMENT }
virtual jsonOutputFile: abap.rawstring(0),

@Semantics.mimeType: true
@ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_VIRTUAL_CALC'
virtual jsonMimeType: abap.char(128),

@ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_VIRTUAL_CALC'
virtual jsonFileName: abap.char(128),

In the ABAP class responsible for virtual element calculation, you simply retrieve the xstring of your file and set its name and type. In my example, we chose to call a function from our behavior definition, but other approaches are possible.

Please note that I removed the <> of field symbols (conflict with the sap community blog post html, don't know why).

CLASS zcl_virtual_calc DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_sadl_exit .
    INTERFACES if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read .
  PROTECTED SECTION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS zcl_virtual_calc IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read~calculate.

    IF it_requested_calc_elements IS INITIAL.
      "Method was called but no virtual elements have been requested -> skip calculation
      RETURN.
    ENDIF.

    LOOP AT it_requested_calc_elements REFERENCE INTO DATA(requested_element).

      LOOP AT it_original_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(original_entity).

        "Get changing line for calculation result
        READ TABLE ct_calculated_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(calculated_data) INDEX sy-tabix.
        IF sy-subrc <> 0.
          CONTINUE.
        ENDIF.

        DATA(original) = CORRESPONDING zc_myobjectconsumptionview( original_entity ).

        CASE requested_element->*.

          WHEN 'JSONMIMETYPE'.
            ASSIGN COMPONENT requested_element->* OF STRUCTURE calculated_data TO FIELD-SYMBOL(field_value).
            IF field_value IS ASSIGNED.
              field_value = |application/json|.
            ENDIF.

          WHEN 'JSONFILENAME'.
            ASSIGN COMPONENT requested_element->* OF STRUCTURE calculated_data TO field_value.
            IF field_value IS ASSIGNED.
              field_value = |file name_{ original-period }.json|.
            ENDIF.

          WHEN 'JSONOUTPUTFILE'.
            ASSIGN COMPONENT requested_element->* OF STRUCTURE calculated_data TO field_value.
            IF field_value IS ASSIGNED.

              READ ENTITIES OF zr_myobjectbehviour
                ENTITY Header
                  EXECUTE exportjsonfilefunction
                  FROM VALUE #( ( %key-uuidkey = original-uuidkey ) )
                RESULT FINAL(result)
                FAILED FINAL(failed)
                REPORTED FINAL(reported).

              READ TABLE result ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(field_value) INDEX 1.
              IF sy-subrc = 0.
                field_value = -%param-file_content. "Should be xstring !
              ENDIF.
            ENDIF.

          WHEN OTHERS.
            CONTINUE.

        ENDCASE.

      ENDLOOP.

      UNASSIGN .

    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read~get_calculation_info.

    LOOP AT it_requested_calc_elements REFERENCE INTO DATA(requested_element).

      CASE requested_element->*.

        WHEN 'JSONOUTPUTFILE' OR 'JSONMIMETYPE' OR 'JSONFILENAME'.
          INSERT |PERIOD| INTO TABLE et_requested_orig_elements.

        WHEN OTHERS.
          CONTINUE.

      ENDCASE.

    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

Finally, you need to add the file field to your object page using the appropriate annotations.

.identification: [ { position: 50 } ]
@UI.fieldGroup: [ { qualifier: 'GeneralInformations', position: 50 } ]
@EndUserText.label: 'JSON file'
jsonOutputFile;

The result is a download link available directly on the object page.

entry.title: Building a Real RAP Application Step by Step ‚Äî Vlog Series Introduction
entry.content:
Introduction

This vlog series aims to demonstrate how to build a real-life ABAP RAP application, following a practical, incremental, and production-oriented approach.

Disclaimer:

This series focuses on showcasing how a RAP application can be built incrementally from real functional requirements. The app is intentionally kept practical and educational, rather than exhaustive or fully hardened for production. Some edge cases or potential enhancements are intentionally not covered.

The purpose of the vlog is to share knowledge, demonstrate real development workflows, and contribute to the SAP community, not to deliver a fully polished commercial-grade application.

To allow anyone to follow the vlog series, I will be using an SAP BTP Trial. This environment carries several limitations compared to a customer system, but it is perfectly sufficient for demonstrating the concepts and end-to-end implementation

Instead of showing a pre-built demo or isolated RAP examples, the series walks through the development process from scratch, implementing the application one requirement at a time, exactly as it would be done in an actual ABAP Cloud project.

Each episode focuses on a small, well-defined set of user stories, keeping the learning process smooth and allowing you to see how the application grows after every step. The structure ensures the app is testable from the very beginning, and every enhancement is immediately visible in the UI preview.

If you want to understand RAP not just in theory but in practice, including determinations, validations, feature control, actions, side effects, completeness checks, semantic keys, and UI configuration, this series is for you.

 

What are we going to build?

We‚Äôll be developing an internal equipment request application for a consulting firm.

Employees can request items kept in internal stock (laptops, monitors, headsets, etc.).

Each request follows a simple lifecycle:

  • Not Prepared / In Preparation / Delivered / (later also Cancelled)

Each request includes header data (requester, deadline, priority, status) and one or more items referencing products from a customizing table of available materials.

The scenario is intentionally simple but rich enough to cover the most important RAP concepts: CDS data modeling, RAP behavior definitions in managed scenarios, Semantic keys, Determinations & validations, UI annotations, Feature control, Prechecks, Popup actions, Value helps, Inline editing, Integration with customizing tables, ABAP Cloud‚Äìcompliant development practices.

 

How the Vlog is structured

The application is built based on a list of functional requirements expressed as user stories. These stories are implemented in the same order they would typically be addressed in a real project. The format of each episode is:

  • Short and focused (usually covering 1-3 user stories)
  • Incremental (the app evolves visibly every episode)
  • Practical (every change is immediately testable)
  • Aligned with ABAP Cloud guidelines
  • Designed for long-term learning and reference

Whether you're starting with RAP or expanding your expertise, this series aims to provide a clear, realistic, and reusable learning path.

 

Full requirement backlog (User Stories)

Below is the collection of user stories implemented throughout the series, listed in almost the exact order used for development:

US-01: Basic request object: As an employee, I want to create internal equipment requests so that I can receive the products I need.

US-02: Search and Filter capabilities: As a user, I want to search requests using structured filters so that I can quickly locate relevant orders. I need to be able to search through the following criteria:

  • free search field,
  • by Requester (with search help),
  • by Priority (drop-down )
  • by Status (drop-down with multiple selections).

US-03: Sequential External ID and semantic key: As the system, I want to assign each request a sequential external number so that users can reference meaningful IDs.

US-04: Mandatory fields: As a user, I want the system to require Requester Name and Deadline Date so that requests are always complete.

US-05: Deadline validation: As the system, I want to validate that the deadline date is at least one day in the future so that operations can prepare on time.

US-06: Automatic priority determination: As the system, I want priority to be set based on deadline so that urgent requests receive proper attention (High: < 3 days, Medium: <7 days, otherwise, Low).

US-07: Status icons: As a user, I want statuses displayed with colored icons so that I can understand them at a glance.

US-08: Cancel status restrictions: As a user, I want to search for cancelled requests but not manually set status as ‚ÄúCancelled‚Äù so that lifecycle rules are respected.

US-09: Default status: As the system, I want new requests to default to ‚ÄúIn Preparation‚Äù so that the lifecycle begins correctly.

US-10: Status editability rules: As a user, I want status to be editable only after creation so that inconsistencies are avoided.

US-11: Cancel action: As a user, I want to cancel one or more requests from the list so that I can invalidate unnecessary requests.

US-12: Cancellation popup: As a user, I want to cancel and justify cancellations through a popup so that the system enforces to have reasons registered.

US-13: Cancel reason rules: As a user, I want ‚ÄúCancellation Reason‚Äù to be editable only when status is ‚ÄúCancelled‚Äù so that it appears available only when relevant.

US-13b: changing dynamic field hiding approach from CDS into virtual element.

US-14: No editing after cancellation: As the system, I want cancelled requests to become read-only so that historical data is kept intact.

US-15: Product catalog restriction: As a user, I want to select products only from internal stock so that I request only available items. Internal stock is customized through a customizing table.

US-16: Product value help: As a user, I want a value help showing only available products so that selection is efficient.

US-17: Unique product per request: As a system, I want to prevent duplicate products within a request so that items remain consistent.

US-18: Item creation via popup: As a user, I want to create items in a popup and edit them inline so that maintenance is fast and intuitive.

US-19: Make popup fields mandatory: As a system, I want to ensure that the data entered through the Product popup is complete.

US-20: Make item fields mandatory: As a system, I want to ensure that the data entered through the Product object page is complete.

 

Episode Roadmap

Each episode implements a specific subset of user stories. Episodes are planned to be released on a weekly basis (approx.). Episode 1 will be released shortly, before end of year!

 

01Project introduction + Data model basicsUS-01
02Service exposure + First UI (read-only) previewUS-01
03Basic behavior + Search fields (Part 1): Free text + RequesterUS-02 (Requester + Free text)
04Search fields (Part 2): Status & PriorityUS-02 (Status + Priority)
05Semantic key & Sequential numberingUS-03
06Mandatory fields + Deadline validationUS-04 + US-05
07Automatic Priority determination + Status icons & visual enhancementsUS-06 + US-07
08Status behavior rulesUS-08 + US-09 + US-10
09Cancel feature (Part 1)US-11 + US-12
10Cancel feature (Part 2)US-13 + US-13b + US-14
11Item popup creation & inline editingUS-18 + US-19
12Product customizing + availabilityUS-15 + US-16
13Item consistency: prevent duplicatesUS-17

 

If this introduction was helpful, a like or follow would be appreciated as it helps others in the community find the series.

entry.title: Re: Warehouse Physical Inventory document creation, unabl...
entry.content:
Dear @Muhammedali,

In Public Cloud this is standard behavior for the Create Inventory Documents Physical Inventory app (/SCWM/PI_DOC_CREATE)

Blocking indicator = X not editable and Freeze inventory indicator not editable

In Public Cloud, when you create a PI document the system sets Inventory Active (IA) = X at creation time, which immediately blocks relevant actions/movements for the affected bin/stock. SAP explicitly classifies this as expected system behavior even if the planned count date is in the future

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3576794

So the field is shown but not meant to be overridden manually in this app.


What you can do in Public Cloud:

  • If your requirement is create PI document but do NOT block / do freeze, SAP guidance for the blocking case is to raise a feature request

More details below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/2963059

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: How AI-Assisted Process Analyzer Lets Any Business User Master Process Intelligence
entry.content:
Ask a Question, Get an Instant Insight: The Power of Text to Insights

Imagine simply typing your question about a key performance indicator, timeframe, or process variant in plain language‚Äîand getting back instant, clear, tailored insights without building dashboards or understanding complex data models. Is this a dream? No, that‚Äôs the magic of the new text to insights feature. The system interprets your intent, runs the analysis behind the scenes, and presents you with findings that explain what‚Äôs happening and why. This slashes the time from question to answer to seconds, accelerating transformation and letting expert analysts focus on high-impact strategic work instead of routine queries.

Benefits:

  • Boost business decision-making speed by up to 50%*
  • Gain automated insights tailored for easy consumption by business users
  • Democratize process intelligence for widespread access and usability

*Disclaimer: Values mentioned in this slide are estimates based on average industry benchmark numbers from an SAP analysis. Customers interested in a specific business case calculation can consult their SAP account team. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

AI-assisted process analyzer, text to insights

Click here to start a step-by-step enable now tutorial for this feature. 

Build Your Visuals by Conversation: Text to Widget

Creating compelling dashboards is now just as simple. The text to widget feature allows users to generate dashboard visuals like bar charts and value tiles by describing what they need in plain language. The AI automatically configures the right visuals and pins them to your workspace for ongoing monitoring. It‚Äôs enhanced to generate and utilize SIGNAL queries as needed, ensuring you have the most relevant insights at your fingertips.

This self-service analytics capability means you no longer need technical training to create the views that matter most to you and your team. Visual data storytelling becomes quicker, fostering better decision-making and smoother collaboration across departments.

This conversational approach sparks a culture of self-service analytics, empowering non-technical stakeholders to visualize and adapt their process views on demand, driving faster, data-driven decisions and more engaging meetings.

Benefits:

  • Save time with personalized widgets tailored to your needs
  • Make data analysis accessible to everyone across your organization
  • Speed up decision-making by prioritizing insights over technical setup

AI-assisted process analyzer, text to widget


 Click here to start a step-by-step enable now tutorial for this feature. 

Simplifying Complex Data: AI-Powered Event Mapping (in Beta)

One of the biggest challenges in process intelligence is aligning vast, messy system event logs‚Äîoften filled with hundreds of events in different languages and with varying labels‚Äîto simpler, readable BPMN models activities. Traditionally, this mapping was manual, tedious, and error-prone.

Get to know event Mapping, the AI-driven event matching feature currently in beta. This advanced tool intelligently aligns system events with business process activities, adeptly handling abbreviations, typos, multilingual labels, and naming variations. Learning from past mappings, it becomes smarter over time, enhancing accuracy and significantly reducing manual effort and errors. Enjoy precise and reusable mappings that enrich dashboards, boost conformance checks, and support rule-based automation, enhancing consistency and speed across the SAP Signavio Suite.

Benefits:

  • Streamline your processes by eliminating manual event matching
  • Enhance usability for a more intuitive experience
  • Accelerate process analysis and improve accuracy

AI-assisted process analyzer, text to widget

Elevating Process Intelligence: Facilitating Business-Wide Collaboration and Insight

These innovations mark a paradigm shift: process intelligence isn‚Äôt just for experts anymore. AI-Assisted Process Analyzer transforms complex process data into an accessible, conversational resource embedded right within SAP Signavio. It encourages a culture of curiosity and collaboration‚Äîacross IT, operations, and business teams‚Äîenabling faster, smarter decisions.

Whether you‚Äôre asking detailed questions, visualizing results on the fly, or simplifying complex event mappings, AI-powered process analytics puts the power in everyone‚Äôs hands. It‚Äôs not just process mining; it‚Äôs process intelligence made easy.
