entry.title: Upgrade S/4HANA 1809 FP2 ‚Äì 2021 SP3 SDMI Downtime Optimization
entry.content:
Introduction

In many S/4HANA upgrade programs, the focus is heavily placed on completing SUM successfully. However, in large enterprise systems, the real risk to downtime and cutover stability often comes after SUM execution begins, specifically from Silent Data Migration Interface (SDMI).

SDMI is designed to move data conversion out of technical downtime and into uptime wherever possible. In practice, when SDMI is not architected deliberately, it can extend downtime, overload the database, and delay business validation‚Äîespecially in systems processing hundreds of millions or billions of records.

This article shares practical, field-tested experience from a large-scale S/4HANA upgrade where SDMI initially ran for multiple days and later was reduced to single-digit hours through architectural changes rather than trial-and-error tuning.

Why SDMI Becomes a Critical Risk Area

In high-volume systems, SDMI often becomes the longest-running activity during or immediately after the upgrade. Common symptoms include:

  • SDMI classes running for days during SUM post-processing

  • Unpredictable execution behavior across upgrade cycles

  • Heavy database update statements dominating runtime

  • Business validation blocked until SDMI completion

In this project, SDMI classes related to Commodity Management and Agricultural Contract Management processed over a billion records, making default SDMI execution paths impractical from a business downtime perspective.

The key realization was that SDMI is not a background task‚Äîit is a core upgrade workstream that requires architectural ownership.

Understanding Where SDMI Fits in the SUM Lifecycle

By default, SDMI can execute in several places:

  • During SUM uptime phases

  • At the SUM breakpoint RUN_SDMI_POST_PROCESSING

  • Outside SUM, executed manually or via background jobs

For smaller systems, running SDMI inside SUM may be acceptable. For large systems, allowing heavy SDMI classes to execute within SUM can consume the entire cutover window.

In early upgrade cycles, SDMI execution at the post-processing breakpoint extended SUM completion by multiple days, directly impacting SPAU/SPDD activities and delaying business sign-off.

 

Architectural Decision: Decouple Heavy SDMI from SUM

Rather than continuing to tune within SUM, the approach was changed fundamentally:

  • Light SDMI classes remained inside SUM

  • High-volume SDMI classes were deliberately excluded from SUM execution

  • Heavy classes were executed outside SUM during controlled uptime windows

This architectural separation achieved three important outcomes:

  1. Protected SUM technical downtime

  2. Allowed performance tuning without SUM constraints

  3. Enabled better monitoring, restart, and recovery options

The upgrade moved from a ‚Äúhope-and-wait‚Äù model to a controlled execution strategy.

 

Performance Optimization Beyond Parallelism

Increasing work processes alone did not resolve SDMI performance issues. The biggest improvements came from addressing database behavior and SDMI framework logic.

Key actions included:

  • Applying targeted SAP Notes addressing SDMI performance and SQL optimization

  • Reducing unnecessary updates by skipping already ‚Äúrealized‚Äù records

  • Resetting SDMI migration state correctly before reprocessing

  • Monitoring SQL execution time using ST12 and database tools

Once database-level inefficiencies were resolved, SDMI runtime dropped dramatically‚Äîwithout additional hardware.

Results Achieved

After re-architecting SDMI execution and applying targeted corrections:

  • SDMI runtime reduced from multiple days to hours

  • SUM downtime became predictable and repeatable

  • Business validation started on schedule

  • SDMI classes completed cleanly with correct completion status

Most importantly, upgrade confidence increased across subsequent cycles because execution behavior was no longer unpredictable.

Key Lessons Learned

From this experience, a few lessons stand out clearly:

  • SDMI must be planned as part of upgrade architecture, not treated as a technical afterthought

  • SUM downtime should be protected aggressively‚Äîdo not allow large SDMI classes to run blindly

  • Database query behavior matters more than raw CPU or memory

  • Selective SDMI execution is the most effective lever for downtime reduction

  • Production-like sandbox testing is essential for timeline accuracy

Conclusion

Silent Data Migration Interface can either enable a smooth S/4HANA upgrade‚Äîor quietly derail it. The difference lies not in hardware sizing, but in architectural decisions about where and how SDMI executes.

By decoupling heavy SDMI classes from SUM, focusing on database-centric optimization, and treating SDMI as a first-class upgrade workstream, even the largest enterprise systems can achieve predictable, business-friendly upgrade timelines and this comes within Business downtime timelines.

entry.title: SAP Clean Core for TOGAF Practitioners
entry.content:
Your organization is using The Open Group Architecture Framework (TOGAF) for managing enterprise architecture, and you want to implement the SAP clean core approach.[Think of a clean core as ERP without the baggage]

  • TOGAF provides the overarching, vendor-neutral methodology and governance structure for managing enterprise architecture
  • SAP clean core defines specific, prescriptive rules and guardrails for the application architecture within an SAP ecosystem. 
  • TOGAF‚Äôs Architecture domains, such as business architecture, information system and data architecture and technology architecture, are closely linked with Clean Core dimensions, such as Business process, (application) Extension, Data, Integration and Operations

Figure 1: TOGAF ADM, Clean Core dimensions, Clean Core principles

How can TOGAF Practitioners adopt Clean Core Principles?

TOGAF practitioners integrate clean core principles into their projects by embedding clean core activities within the various phases of the Architecture Development Method (ADM)

ADM Phase

Key Activities for SAP Clean Core Implementation

Tools

Preliminary

Establishes the architectural framework, principles, and scope.

Define the "Clean Core" principle as a core architectural standard.

SAP LeanIX

Phase A: Architecture Vision

Defines the scope, stakeholders, and the target architecture vision.

Establish the vision of a stable, upgrade-safe Cloud ERP core system 

  • Identify high-level business goals and objectives for each clean core dimension
  • Identify key stakeholders for each clean core dimension
  • Define architecture scope [boundary]

SAP LeanIX

SAP Signavio

Phase B: Business Architecture

Develops the baseline and target business architectures, identifying gaps.

Business Processes

  • Conduct a 'Fit-to-standard' assessment and determine processes that require unique, differentiating extensions.
  • Enhance business processes for competitiveness while reducing complexity.
  • Prioritize and segment processes into layers (commodity, differentiating, innovating).

SAP LeanIX

SAP Signavio

Joule for Consultants

Phase C: Information Systems Architecture

Develops Data and Application Architectures (baseline and target).

(Application) Extension:

  • Use SAP provide extension framework
  • Decouple extensions
  • Enable users for key user extensibility

Data:

  • Control data according to latest standards
  • Streamline data usage across applications
  • Rationalize enterprise structure by effectively utilizing configuration
  • Integrate master data and transaction data hygiene into business processes

Application Extension

SAP BTP

SAP Build

Cloud ABAP

ATC Check

Data

SAP Master Data Governance

 

Phase D : Technology Architecture

Defines the target technology platform and infrastructure.

Integration:

  • Use API first
  • Utilize SAP's integration framework

Operations:

  • Establish governance for managing infrastructure, upgrade decisions, extension decisions, and system monitoring and maintenance activities

SAP Integration Suite

SAP Cloud ALM

The remaining ADM Phases will take inputs from the Phases B, C, and D

Phase E : Opportunities and Solutions

Identify options and solutions to bridge the gap between the current (as-is) and target architectures.

Identify Clean Core opportunities

  • Monitor clean core dashboards to find opportunities to streamline processes, improving data quality or reducing custom code
  • Periodically perform clean core maturity assessments to find improvement opportunities

Signavio Process Insights

Clean Core dashboards

Clean Core KPI measurements

Phase F: Migration Planning

Formulates a detailed implementation and migration plan.

Plan Clean Core activities

  • Prioritize work packages for implementing standard process
  • Decommissioning legacy custom code and migrating to the cloud

SAP Signavio

SAP Cloud ALM

Phase G: Implementation Governance

Provides architectural oversight of the implementation projects.

Clean Core governances and oversight

  • Utilize solution standardization board
  • Conduct architecture reviews of implementation projects to ensure adherence to principles

Clean Core dashboards

ATC

Clean Core Maturity Assessment

 

Phase H: Architecture Change Management.

Manages ongoing changes to the new architecture.

Transparency and communication for Clean Core

  • Provide architecture domain ownership to maintain their architecture artifacts (e.g. BCM, Business Processes, Data model etc.)
  • Utilize enterprise architecture management tools to provide ownership and visibility to domain owners

SAP LeanIX

SAP Signavio

Requirements Management

A continuous process ensuring all requirements are managed, documented, and traceable throughout the ADM cycle.

Clean Core Requirements Management

  • Continuously validate that new business objectives and requirements are met through standard functionality
  • Focus on non-functional and technical requirements to ensure that the platform is up to date to meet users expected needs and aspirations

SAP LeanIX

SAP Cloud ALM

By aligning SAP Clean Core principles with TOGAF‚Äôs ADM phases, organizations can incorporate clean principles in their existing way of working.

Please contact your SAP account team or Enterprise Architect for additional information.

entry.title: The 8D Architectural Framework for SAP ERP Modernization: A Practitioner‚Äôs View
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • 1D ‚Äî Regulatory Envelope
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 2D ‚Äî AI Ambition vs. Process Intelligence Reality
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 3D ‚Äî Data Governance as Technical Foundation
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 4D ‚Äî Clean Core Extensibility (SAP BTP-Centric Architecture)
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 5D ‚Äî Deployment Model as an Architectural Outcome
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 6D ‚Äî Change Management for Technical Adoption
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 7D ‚Äî Competitive Timeline (Architecture Maturity Curve)
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • 8D ‚Äî 15-Year Architectural Vision (Composable, AI-Ready ERP)
  • Why it matters
  • Architect‚Äôs takeaway
  • Conclusion
  • Call for Discussion

Introduction

After 20 years across SAP roles (ABAP through Pre-Sales Architecture), I've observed one constant: transformation projects fail not because of technical complexity, but because architects evaluate decisions along too few dimensions. This 8D ERP Transformation Framework provides the lens for holistic evaluation. This framework emerges from observing S/4HANA 2025 release capabilities and the architectural options they enable. 

Architects succeed when they evaluate ERP transformation through multiple dimensions, not just scope or timelines.

This 8D ERP Transformation Framework is a practical lens for architects, technical leads, and industry experts to evaluate modernization decisions holistically ‚Äî aligning with SAP best practices while ensuring long-term architectural integrity.

1D ‚Äî Regulatory Envelope

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Before discussing deployment models or system design, architects should begin with a clear understanding of industry-specific regulatory constraints. Not as limitation‚Äîas the architectural guardrails that enable good design. Pharma needs GxP-validated processes. Banking needs SOX audit trails. Healthcare needs HIPAA data residency. These requirements, when understood first, shape architectures that are both compliant AND competitive.

Why it matters

  • Determines data residency, encryption, auditability
  • Influences deployment model suitability (public, private, hybrid)
  • Shapes integration patterns (secure interfaces, segregation of duties)
  • Impacts AI governance and validation requirements

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Start here. Regulation isn‚Äôt a blocker ‚Äî it provides the boundaries within which good architecture is designed.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are architects incorporating GxP, SOX, or enterprise data sovereignty into their S/4HANA designs?‚Äù

2D ‚Äî AI Ambition vs. Process Intelligence Reality

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
AI potential is immense, but technical feasibility depends on process maturity and system standardization.

Why it matters

  • AI needs predictable, event-driven processes
  • Variants or undocumented steps make automation unreliable
  • Process mining (Signavio, Celonis) gives architects clarity on actual execution paths
  • Architectural patterns must align with future AI scenarios

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Map ‚Üí standardize ‚Üí instrument ‚Üí automate.
AI-readiness should be treated as a technical design requirement, not a future add-on.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are teams using process intelligence during Explore/Design phases to define AI-ready to-be processes?‚Äù

3D ‚Äî Data Governance as Technical Foundation

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
ERP modernization gives architects a rare opportunity to redesign master data models, lineage, governance, and integration semantics.

Why it matters

  • Data lineage is essential for audit and AI explainability
  • Data quality (>95% accuracy) supports automation reliability
  • Master Data governance enables clean integration landscapes
  • Event-driven designs require consistent data domains

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Treat data governance as a core architecture pillar ‚Äî not a post-go-live enhancement.
Modern ERP + AI depends on structured, governed data models.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúWhat architecture patterns (Datasphere, MDM, governance councils) are teams adopting to ensure cross-system consistency?‚Äù

4D ‚Äî Clean Core Extensibility (SAP BTP-Centric Architecture)

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Clean core is an architectural strategy that balances stability with innovation. It aligns tightly with SAP‚Äôs guidance while enabling teams to innovate using BTP.

Why it matters

  • Core remains upgrade-friendly, consistent, and supportable
  • Extensions move to BTP (RAP, CAP, ABAP Cloud)
  • Reduces complexity, accelerates lifecycle management
  • API-first design supports AI, mobility, and cloud-native integrations

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Design for extensibility beyond the core.
Architects should evaluate each customization:

  • Is this differentiating?
  • Can it live on BTP?
  • Can it follow RAP/CAP patterns?

Example: Procurement customization. Is it differentiating? If yes, build on BTP using RAP patterns. Is it standard? Keep in core. Can it use ABAP Cloud with stable APIs? Yes. This decision-tree approach prevents accumulation of technical debt.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are architects managing custom code remediation and defining clean-core guardrails during design?‚Äù

5D ‚Äî Deployment Model as an Architectural Outcome

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Public Cloud, Private Cloud, On-Premise, and Hybrid models each have strengths. The right choice emerges after evaluating regulatory, data, integration, and extensibility needs.

Why it matters

  • Public Cloud offers rapid innovation and standardization
  • Private Cloud offers control, extensibility, and harmonization flexibility
  • Hybrid architectures support OT/IoT-heavy industries
  • Deployment must align with technical and business constraints

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Deployment selection is a conclusion ‚Äî not the starting point.
Architects should let the earlier dimensions drive the model.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are teams balancing innovation velocity with integration depth when selecting deployment models?‚Äù

6D ‚Äî Change Management for Technical Adoption

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Change management isn‚Äôt just business-focused. Architects must plan for technical change adoption: new workflows, new UX, new AI features, new integration patterns.

Why it matters

  • AI-enabled ERP shifts user behavior
  • Role design must consider AI agents and automated tasks
  • Continuous enablement ensures stable operations
  • Architecture must support explainability and feedback loops

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Technical design must include a human adoption model.
UX, security, audit, and automation patterns must be communicated early.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are architects designing role/permission models for AI-augmented processes?‚Äù

7D ‚Äî Competitive Timeline (Architecture Maturity Curve)

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
Timelines are not only logistical ‚Äî they determine how fast architecture matures to support modern capabilities.

Why it matters

  • Event-driven integrations, BTP services, and AI agents require iterative maturation
  • Early modernization accelerates capability-building
  • Late modernization compresses architecture redesign into a shorter window

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Treat modernization as capability-building, not only project execution.
Teams that start earlier build deeper technical skillsets and more stable architectures.

Real data point: Organizations that began S/4HANA transformation in 2023-2024 now deploy new capabilities 3x faster than those starting in 2025-2026, not just because of resource availability but because their technical teams have matured architectural thinking. Early movers built composable architectures; late movers are compressed into shortcuts.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúHow are organizations sequencing modernization waves to align with capability growth?‚Äù

8D ‚Äî 15-Year Architectural Vision (Composable, AI-Ready ERP)

Architect‚Äôs perspective:
S/4HANA support extends to 2040, meaning today‚Äôs architecture must support a decade of evolving AI, integration, and business models.

Why it matters

  • Composability allows modular replacements without major disruption
  • API-first architecture enables multi-platform ecosystems
  • Datasphere, event mesh, knowledge graphs, and vector stores reshape data layers
  • Hybrid/multi-cloud is increasingly standard

Architect‚Äôs takeaway

Architect beyond go-live.
Design for interoperability, scale, observability, and long-term flexibility.

Community discussion angle:
‚ÄúWhat architectural patterns ensure ERP landscapes remain adaptable through 2035‚Äì2040?‚Äù

Conclusion

These eight dimensions guide architects to design ERP landscapes that are:

  • technically robust,
  • clean-core aligned,
  • governable,
  • scalable,
  • AI-ready,
  • and compliant with SAP best practices.

They are not sequential ‚Äî they are an interconnected model. Skip any dimension, and the others collapse under unexamined assumptions. Architects who evaluate all eight simultaneously design landscapes that survive 2030 and thrive through 2040. Those who optimize one or two while ignoring the rest? They're designing for today's constraints while tomorrow's competitors design for tomorrow's capabilities.

Call for Discussion 

  • Which dimensions are shaping your S/4HANA architecture most strongly today? Please share in comments‚ÄîI'll synthesize responses into a follow-up article on 'The 80/20: Which Two Dimensions Determine 80% of Success.

entry.title: Dual line chart using macros and odata v4
entry.content:
Dear experts,

I am facing some problems to implement a chart in Fiori, using macros, xml annotations and odata v4. It works when I only have one dimension, but fails when the second is included.

The annotation "@Aggregation.default: #SUM" is included in the entity view, and the xml annotation is being used as follow:

<edmx:Edmx xmlns:edmx="http://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/ns/edmx" Version="4.0">
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/Analytics.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.Analytics.v1" Alias="Analytics"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://oasis-tcs.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/Org.OData.Aggregation.V1.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="Org.OData.Aggregation.V1" Alias="Aggregation"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/Common.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.Common.v1" Alias="Common"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://oasis-tcs.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/Org.OData.Capabilities.V1.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="Org.OData.Capabilities.V1" Alias="Capabilities"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/HTML5.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.HTML5.v1" Alias="HTML5"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/UI.xml">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1" Alias="UI"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:Reference Uri="/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zui_newblick/srvd/sap/zsd_newblick/0001/$metadata">
        <edmx:Include Namespace="com.sap.gateway.srvd.zsd_newblick.v0001" Alias="SAP__self"/>
    </edmx:Reference>
    <edmx:DataServices>
        <Schema xmlns="http://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/ns/edm" Namespace="local">

            <Annotations Target="SAP__self.Container/ZI_BLK_OPEN_RESOLVED">
                <Annotation Term="Aggregation.ApplySupported">
                    <Record Type="Aggregation.ApplySupportedType">
                        <PropertyValue Property="Transformations">
                            <Collection>
                                <String>aggregate</String>
                                <String>groupby</String>
                            </Collection>
                        </PropertyValue>
                        <PropertyValue Property="AggregatableProperties">
                            <Collection>
                                <Record Type="Aggregation.AggregatablePropertyType">
                                    <PropertyValue Property="Property">
                                        <PropertyPath>openTickets</PropertyPath>
                                    </PropertyValue>
                                </Record>
                                <Record Type="Aggregation.AggregatablePropertyType">
                                    <PropertyValue Property="Property">
                                        <PropertyPath>resolvedTickets</PropertyPath>
                                    </PropertyValue>
                                </Record>
                            </Collection>
                        </PropertyValue>
                        <PropertyValue Property="GroupableProperties">
                            <Collection>
                                <PropertyPath>openResolvedDate</PropertyPath>
                            </Collection>
                        </PropertyValue>
                    </Record>
                </Annotation>
            </Annotations>

            <Annotations Target="SAP__self.ZI_BLK_OPEN_RESOLVEDType">
                
                <Annotation Term="UI.Chart" Qualifier="TicketsOpenResolved">
					<Record Type="UI.ChartDefinitionType">
						<PropertyValue Property="Title" String="Open x Resolved" />
						<PropertyValue Property="ChartType" EnumMember="UI.ChartType/Line" />
						<PropertyValue Property="Description" String="Open x Resolved Tickets" />
                        <PropertyValue Property="Dimensions">
							<Collection>
								<PropertyPath>openResolvedDate</PropertyPath>
							</Collection>
						</PropertyValue>
                        <PropertyValue Property="DimensionAttributes">
							<Collection>
								<Record Type="UI.ChartDimensionAttributeType">
									<PropertyValue Property="Dimension" PropertyPath="openResolvedDate" />
									<PropertyValue Property="Role" EnumMember="UI.ChartDimensionRoleType/Category" />
								</Record>
							</Collection>
						</PropertyValue>
                        <PropertyValue Property="Measures">
                            <Collection>
                                <PropertyPath>openTickets</PropertyPath>
                                <PropertyPath>resolvedTickets</PropertyPath>
                            </Collection>
                        </PropertyValue>
                        <PropertyValue Property="DynamicMeasures">
                            <Collection>
                                <AnnotationPath>@Analytics.AggregatedProperty</AnnotationPath>
                                <AnnotationPath>@Analytics.AggregatedProperty#ResolvedSum</AnnotationPath>
                            </Collection>
                        </PropertyValue>
						<PropertyValue Property="MeasureAttributes">
							<Collection>
								<Record Type="UI.ChartMeasureAttributeType">
									<PropertyValue Property="Measure" PropertyPath="openTickets" />
									<PropertyValue Property="Role" EnumMember="UI.ChartMeasureRoleType/Axis1" />
								</Record>
                                <Record Type="UI.ChartMeasureAttributeType">
                                    <PropertyValue Property="Measure" PropertyPath="resolvedTickets" />
                                    <PropertyValue Property="Role" EnumMember="UI.ChartMeasureRoleType/Axis1" />
                                </Record>
							</Collection>
						</PropertyValue>
						
					</Record>
				</Annotation>

                <Annotation Term="Analytics.AggregatedProperty">
                    <Record Type="Analytics.AggregatedPropertyType" >
                        <PropertyValue Property="Name" String="openSum"/>
                        <PropertyValue Property="AggregationMethod" String="sum"/>
                        <PropertyValue Property="AggregatableProperty" PropertyPath="openTickets"/>
                        <Annotation Term="Common.Label" String="Open Tickets"/>
                    </Record>
                </Annotation>
                <Annotation Term="Analytics.AggregatedProperty" Qualifier="ResolvedSum" >
                    <Record Type="Analytics.AggregatedPropertyType">
                        <PropertyValue Property="Name" String="resolvedSum"/>
                        <PropertyValue Property="AggregationMethod" String="sum"/>
                        <PropertyValue Property="AggregatableProperty" PropertyPath="resolvedTickets"/>
                        <Annotation Term="Common.Label" String="Resolved Tickets"/>
                    </Record>
                </Annotation>

            </Annotations>

        </Schema>
    </edmx:DataServices>
</edmx:Edmx>

The chart opens with the message "To start, set the relevant filters and choose "Go" when even there isn't any filter to be applied. 

Its associated batch call returns the errors:  "Dynamic property 'openSum' not provided by provider application", "Property 'openSum' not found". The attribute in the backend entity is openTickets, and the aggregated property in the xml annotation is "openSum", which doesn't fail with only one dimension, but It does fail with two. 

<Annotation Term="Analytics.AggregatedProperty">
                    <Record Type="Analytics.AggregatedPropertyType" >
                        <PropertyValue Property="Name" String="openSum"/>
                        <PropertyValue Property="AggregationMethod" String="sum"/>
                        <PropertyValue Property="AggregatableProperty" PropertyPath="openTickets"/>
                        <Annotation Term="Common.Label" String="Open Tickets"/>
                    </Record>
                </Annotation>
                <Annotation Term="Analytics.AggregatedProperty" Qualifier="ResolvedSum" >
                    <Record Type="Analytics.AggregatedPropertyType">
                        <PropertyValue Property="Name" String="resolvedSum"/>
                        <PropertyValue Property="AggregationMethod" String="sum"/>
                        <PropertyValue Property="AggregatableProperty" PropertyPath="resolvedTickets"/>
                        <Annotation Term="Common.Label" String="Resolved Tickets"/>
                    </Record>
                </Annotation>

What could be wrong in my xml annotation?

entry.title: Cloud ALM - Alert Overview ‚Äì Integration & Exception Monitoring Example
entry.content:
User Guide

The Alert section in the navigation bar of SAP Cloud ALM provides a central overview of all current and historical alerts detected by Integration & Exception Monitoring. Users can quickly identify issues, analyze technical details, and take appropriate actions directly in Cloud ALM.

1. Alert Name and Message

This column displays the name of the alert in Cloud ALM. The name describes the type of warning or exception, for example around-neuros-message-i-doc-detected-off-grouped-to.
The alert name provides an initial indication of the issue or event that occurred.

2. Managed Components / Service

Directly below the alert name in Cloud ALM, the associated service is displayed. This entry indicates which service or system triggered the alert.

3. Object Details

This column shows technical details of the alert in Cloud ALM.

By clicking on the alert name in Cloud ALM, the user is taken to a detailed view with additional information about the alert. This includes possible root causes, affected systems, and recommended actions.

Alert Details (Detailed Alert View in SAP Cloud ALM)

When clicking on the alert name in Cloud ALM, a detailed view opens with extended information about the specific incident. This view allows users to trace the timeline, affected technical objects, and their current status directly in the system.

1. Status Information

 

 

The current alert status in Cloud ALM is displayed, for example:

  • Status: Open

  • Priority: High

  • Current Rating: Red

  • Worst Rating: Red

  • Last Update: Date & Time

  • Created: Date & Time

  • Processor: Assigned responsible person

2. Timeline

A timeline in Cloud ALM shows how long the alert has existed. For example, it may indicate that an error status repeatedly occurred over several months, from June 1, 2024, until January 2025.

3. Technical Objects

 

Overview of Affected iDocs and Messages in Cloud ALM

This section lists all relevant iDocs and messages tracked in Cloud ALM. Key attributes

 

4. Actions

An Actions button is available directly in Cloud ALM.

Using the Actions button in Cloud ALM, the following steps can be performed:

  • Confirm: Mark the alert as reviewed or resolved (without deleting it)

  • Add Comments: Add comments for documentation or coordination

  • Processor: Assign the alert to a responsible person

  • Set Email Notification: Enable email notifications for users or groups

  • Start Operation Flow: Start a predefined workflow or escalation process

  • Create Ticket: Automatically create a ticket in an ITSM system

  • Send Chat Notification: Send notifications to chat tools such as Microsoft Teams or Slack

 

Add Comments (Cloud ALM)

This function allows users to add comments directly to an alert, for example ‚ÄúI will take over the alert‚Äù.
This makes responsibilities transparent, supports collaboration (e.g., during absences), and prevents duplicate work.

 

Alert History (Cloud ALM)

 

  • All actions performed via the Actions button (e.g., comments, changes) are automatically logged

  • Each change includes the name of the user

  • The complete alert history is always traceable

  • Result: full documentation, transparency, and clear traceability

 

Processor (Cloud ALM)

  • Assignment or removal of a responsible person for the alert

  • Clear definition of ownership

  • Supports structured task allocation and avoids duplicate work

 

Assign Processor (Cloud ALM)

 

When clicking Assign Processor in Cloud ALM, a dialog opens where the responsible person is entered via email address.
An additional comment can be added, e.g., ‚Äúplease take over this alert‚Äù, to make the handover transparent.
Clicking Save confirms the assignment.

Key points:

  • The processor is identified by email address

  • Comments support explanation and coordination

  • Saving confirms the assignment and may trigger notifications

Manual Email Notification (Cloud ALM)

 

Using the Email Notification button, alerts can be manually forwarded to individuals or groups in Cloud ALM.
Recipients are entered in the To field. The subject and message body are prefilled with the most important alert details.

Conclusion

By following these steps in SAP Cloud ALM, users can ensure transparent monitoring, quick issue resolution, and efficient management of all integration and exception alerts.

entry.title: Re: Considerations when implementing IAS for SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content:
Hi @NathanWilkinson,

We got this to work in Dev but through my testing and in your screenshot above, we noticed that the onboardee has access to "change" their first name and last name when they create a password using the email sent from IAS.

How do we make the name fields read-only at this stage for them? We don't want them to be able to do this as 1) legal and preferred names are captured and verified in SF already and, 2) whatever they change here will just be overwritten by the next synch job.

This will only create confusion for them and make them think it's a defect.

Thanks

entry.title: Cloud ALM User Authorization ‚Äì Example with Real User Monitoring
entry.content:
Cloud ALM User Authorization: Example with Real User Monitoring

Real User Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM allows administrators and users to track and manage system usage efficiently. In this guide, we show how to navigate to Real User Monitoring and ensure that the right authorizations are in place.

After logging in, you will arrive at the Cloud ALM dashboard.

 

From here, you can access Real User Monitoring to check the status of users and their activities. Follow these steps:

 

Step 1: Access Real User Monitoring

 

  • From the main menu, select Operations or Monitoring (depending on your system version).

  • Click on Real User Monitoring or End User Monitoring.

Note: If the Real User Monitoring tile is not visible, you likely lack the required authorization. Please contact your administrator to gain access.

 

Step 2: View Users

 

  • Click on User by Status to display all users in Cloud ALM.

  • Use the search bar in the top-left corner to find your name.

  • Click on your entry to open user-specific details.

 

Step 3: Assign Roles

  • In the right-hand panel, add your roles for Real User Monitoring

  • Once your roles are added, the relevant tiles and monitoring features will become visible.

 

Conclusion

Proper user authorization in SAP Cloud ALM is essential to ensure that users have the right access to system features, dashboards, and monitoring tools. By managing roles and permissions effectively, organizations can maintain security, enable transparency, and empower users to perform their tasks efficiently without compromising system integrity.
